The plants which produce flower are called flowering plants.

In this chapter, we shall be acquainted with chilli plant, which we frequently see and regularly use.
Chilli: Chilli is an ingredient of spice for most of our cooking.
Besides, it is a cash crop of this country.
Two types of chillis are cultivated in Bangladesh: sweet chilli and hot chilli.
Both the types include different varieties.
Scientific name of the chilli that we most commonly use is Capcum fruticens.
This plant is a herb.
It is used as spice as well as in preparing sauce.
Sweet chilli is used as vegetable and in salad too.
Chilli is a flowering plant.
It has tap root system.
In addition, it bears stem, branches, leaves, flowers and fruits.
The plant is profusely branched and bushy.
The leaves are alternate with short or long petioles and the leaf apex is acute.
In the leaf axil of sweet chilli a single flower develops.
In case of hot chilli two or more flowers are found in the axil of a leaf.

All flowering plants have more or less a limited life span.
These plants develop flowers, fruits and seeds.
If requisite amount of light, water and air are available, the seeds germinate to seedlings.
The seedling gradually matures and subsequently produces from flowers and seeds are formed within the fruits.
The seeds germinate to give rise to seedling again.
